  "article_text": [
    "let @xmath0 be a smooth orbifold .",
    "davis asked : `` when is its underlying space @xmath1 a topological manifold''(@xcite , p. 9 ) .",
    "the answer to this question only depends on the structure of the local groups of @xmath0 .",
    "it amounts to the classification of finite subgroups @xmath2 of @xmath3 for which @xmath4 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 . in @xcite",
    ", mikhalova has shown that _ pseudoreflection groups _",
    "fulfill this property .",
    "these are finite subgroups of @xmath3 generated by _ pseudoreflections _ , i.e. by linear transformations whose fixed point subspaces have codimension two .",
    "another example stems from cannon s double suspension theorem @xcite : the binary icosahedral group admits a faithful realization @xmath6 and it follows from cannon s theorem that @xmath7 is homeomorphic to @xmath8 where the action of @xmath9 is extended trivially to the fifth factor . since the quotient space @xmath10 is poincar s homology sphere , we refer to @xmath9 as a _ poincar group_.    in this paper we prove the following results .    for a finite subgroup",
    "@xmath11 the quotient space @xmath4 @xmath12 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 @xmath13 if and only if @xmath2 has the form @xmath14 for a pseudoreflection group @xmath15 and poincar groups @xmath16 , @xmath17 , such that the factors act in pairwise orthogonal spaces and such that @xmath18 @xmath19 if @xmath20 .",
    "in particular , theorem a shows that the underlying space of an orbifold is a topological manifold if and only if all local groups have this special form .",
    "it follows from mikhalova s work , the double suspension theorem and the generalized poincar conjecture that @xmath4 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 for all groups described in the theorem . to show the corresponding assertion in case of theorem b one also needs to know that isotropy groups of pseudoreflection groups are again pseudoreflection groups .",
    "the proof to show that there are no other examples is divided into three steps . in the first step",
    "we observe that if @xmath21 is homeomorphic to @xmath22 , then @xmath4 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 and so , in particular , the quotient space @xmath4 is a homology manifold . using this observation",
    "we deduce that strata of @xmath4 that are not contained in the closure of any higher dimensional singular stratum either have codimension two or codimension four and that the corresponding local groups are either cyclic groups or poincar groups .",
    "these local groups appear as subgroups of @xmath2 fixing certain maximal subspaces of @xmath5 .",
    "taking @xmath23 to be the normal subgroup of @xmath2 generated by all of them , we obtain a `` sufficiently large '' normal subgroup of @xmath2 generated by pseudoreflections and poincar groups .",
    "a key ingredient in this step is a theorem by zassenhaus characterizing the binary icosahedral group .    in the second step we use",
    "an elementary fact about spherical triangles and the specific geometric structure of the 600-cell , i.e. the orbit of one point under the action @xmath24 , to show that the pseudoreflection group and all poincar groups generating @xmath23 act in pairwise orthogonal spaces .",
    "finally , in the last step we show inductively that @xmath25 is a free action on a homology sphere . from this",
    "we deduce that @xmath26 is a perfect group with periodic tate cohomology whose homology groups vanish in dimensions @xmath27 .",
    "such groups are classified and the classification allows us to identify @xmath26 as a trivial group . consequently , @xmath2 coincides with @xmath23 and has thus a form as described in our theorem .    before starting to carry out these steps explicitly , we remind of some necessary concepts and results .",
    "a pseudoreflection of @xmath5 is a linear map @xmath28 whose fixed point subspace has codimension two .",
    "a pseudoreflection group is a finite subgroup of @xmath3 generated by pseudoreflections .",
    "a pseudoreflection necessarily rotates the orthogonal complement of its fixed point subspace .",
    "hence , a pseudoreflection group @xmath29 is orientation preserving , i.e. @xmath30 . examples for pseudoreflection groups are orientation preserving subgroups of coxeter groups and unitary reflection groups considered as real groups . in @xcite , mikhalova obtained the following result about pseudoreflection groups .",
    "( mikhalova , 1982 ) let @xmath30 be a pseudoreflection group .",
    "then the quotient space @xmath31 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 .",
    "[ thm : mikhailova ]      let @xmath32 be the orientation preserving symmetry group of a centered icosahedron in @xmath33 .",
    "the preimage of this subgroup under the canonical lie group covering map @xmath34 is called the _ binary icosahedral group _ and we denote it by @xmath35 . since @xmath36 is two - to - one , we have @xmath37 . moreover , @xmath35 is perfect and isomorphic to @xmath38 ( @xcite , p. 196f ) .",
    "the lie group @xmath39 can be identified with the unit quaternions @xmath40 . under this identification a binary icosahedral group in @xmath39",
    "is given by the union of the @xmath41 hurwitz units @xmath42 together with all @xmath43 unit quaternions obtained from @xmath44 by an even permutation of coordinates , where @xmath45 is the golden ratio @xcite .",
    "from the natural representation of @xmath39 on @xmath46 we obtain a faithful and irreducible representation of the binary icosahedral group on @xmath47 which is equivalent to the representation obtained by left multiplication on @xmath48 .",
    "note that there are two dual representations of @xmath35 on @xmath46 obtained in this way and that these differ by an outer automorphism of @xmath35 ( @xcite , p. 202 ) .",
    "however , the resulting representations on @xmath47 coincide .",
    "we refer to this realization of the binary icosahedral group in @xmath49 as a _ poincar group _ and denote it by @xmath9 .",
    "consider the free action @xmath24 .",
    "since @xmath35 is a perfect group , we have @xmath50 and thus proposition [ prp : connection - group - topological - homology ] and poincar duality imply that @xmath51 i.e. the quotient manifold @xmath52 is a homology sphere .",
    "indeed , it is poincar s homology sphere",
    ".    now we want to describe the geometry of the orbits of the action @xmath24 explicitly .",
    "first note that all orbits are isometric , since the canonical metric on @xmath53 is @xmath53-bi - invariant .",
    "so let @xmath54 be an arbitrary point and let @xmath55 be its orbit under the action of @xmath9 . since @xmath9 is finite , the sets @xmath56 are empty except for a finite number of values for @xmath57 .",
    "the points of @xmath58 lie in the intersection of @xmath53 with a hyperplane of @xmath47 .",
    "this intersection is a point for @xmath59 and a two - dimensional sphere for @xmath60 .",
    "c6 cm    [ cols=\"^,^,^\",options=\"header \" , ]     from the explicit coordinate representation of @xmath9 above we can read off the structure of @xmath61}x_{\\alpha}$ ] .",
    "the last column in the table specifies the geometric structure of the points in @xmath58 . for our proof of our main result the fact that @xmath62}x_{\\alpha}$ ] is not contained in a three - dimensional affine subspace of @xmath47 is crucial .",
    "the poincar conjecture holds in the following form ( @xcite , theorem 10.3.3 , p. 188 ) .",
    "[ thm : gen_poin_conj ] a simply connected homology @xmath63-sphere is a topological @xmath63-sphere .      the following result bases on work by edwards and cannon and was first obtained in full generality by cannon @xcite .",
    "( cannon , 1979 ) the double suspension @xmath64 of a homology @xmath63-sphere @xmath65 is a topological @xmath66-sphere .",
    "[ thm : double_suspension_theorem ]    the double suspension of @xmath65 is homeomorphic to the join of @xmath65 with @xmath67 , i.e. @xmath68 . in this sense , there is a natural embedding @xmath69 .",
    "because of @xmath70 , the space obtained by @xmath71 after removing @xmath72 is not simply connected anymore . hence ,",
    "by transversality the embedding @xmath73 can neither be smooth nor piecewise linear , but has to be `` wild '' in a certain sense @xcite .",
    "now let @xmath74 be the action of a poincar group @xmath6 described in section [ subsec : the_binary_icosahedral_group ] .",
    "the quotient of this action is not a topological manifold : since @xmath52 is not simply connected , the origin of @xmath75 has no simply connected neighborhood .",
    "however , we claim that the quotient of the action @xmath76 is homeomorphic to @xmath8 where we have extended the action @xmath74 trivially to the fifth factor .",
    "indeed , we have @xmath77 by the double suspension theorem and the property @xmath78 of the spherical join ( @xcite , proposition i.5.15 , p. 64 ) .",
    "this example illustrates the difficulties one encounters trying to prove the _ only if _ direction of our main result : the open cone @xmath79 of the topological space @xmath80 is homeomorphic to @xmath8 whereas @xmath65 itself is not even a topological manifold .",
    "homology manifolds are generalizations of topological manifolds @xcite . for our purpose",
    "the following definition suffices .    a _",
    "homology _ @xmath63-manifold is a hausdorff space @xmath65 such that all local homology groups coincide with the local homology groups of @xmath5 , i.e. for all @xmath81 .",
    "@xmath82 holds .    for a topological space @xmath65",
    "we denote its open cone by @xmath79 .",
    "homology manifolds share the following two properties .",
    "[ lem : characterization_of_homology_manifolds ] let @xmath83 be hausdorff spaces .",
    "then the following equivalences hold .",
    "@xmath65 and @xmath84 are homology manifolds if and only if @xmath85 is a homology manifold .",
    "@xmath79 is a homology @xmath86-manifold if and only if @xmath65 is a homology @xmath63-manifold and @xmath87 .",
    "@xmath88 for open subsets @xmath89 and @xmath90 the following knneth formula holds ( @xcite , corollary vi.12.10 , p. 181 ) @xmath91 where @xmath92 .",
    "now the claim follows as in ( @xcite , theorem 16.11 , p. 378 ) .",
    "@xmath93 for @xmath94 let @xmath95 .",
    "by @xmath88 @xmath65 is a homology manifold if and only if @xmath96 is a homology manifold .",
    "we have a long exact sequence of homology groups ( @xcite , p. 117 ) @xmath97 because of @xmath98 and @xmath99 we find that @xmath100 and this shows the claim .",
    "this lemma shows that the underlying space @xmath101 of a finite @xmath63-dimensional simplicial complex @xmath102 is a homology manifold if and only if the link of every vertex of @xmath102 is a homology manifold and has the homology groups of an @xmath103-sphere .",
    "in this situation the following theorem holds , which was first pointed out by edwards for @xmath104 @xcite .",
    "[ thm : simplicialcomplex_hommfd ] let @xmath102 be a finite @xmath63-dimensional simplicial complex @xmath102 such that its underlying topological space @xmath101 is a homology manifold . then @xmath65 is a topological manifold , if and only if the link of every vertex of @xmath102 is simply connected .    for @xmath105",
    "the claim is clear . for @xmath106",
    "all links of the vertices are two - dimensional homology manifolds with the homology groups of a sphere , therefore two - dimensional homology spheres ( @xcite , p. 1090 ) and thus spheres . for @xmath107 the link @xmath108 of a vertex",
    "is a simply connected homology manifold with the homology groups of a sphere . since the links of the vertices of @xmath108 are two - dimensional homology manifolds with the homology groups of a sphere , we see by the above , that @xmath108 is a topological manifold and thus a sphere by the poincar conjecture . for @xmath109",
    "the claim follows by edwards s work on the disjoint disk property ( @xcite , section 8 , p. 119 ) .      for a finite group @xmath110",
    "we denote by @xmath111 its homology groups , by @xmath112 its cohomology groups and by @xmath113 its tate cohomology groups .",
    "these groups are related as follows ( @xcite , p. 135 ) @xmath114 if @xmath110 has periodic tate cohomology groups , we simply say that @xmath110 has _",
    "periodic cohomology_. for our purpose the following class of examples is important .",
    "let @xmath115 be a prime and let @xmath116 , the group of @xmath117 matrices of determinant 1 over the prime field with @xmath115 elements .",
    "then @xmath110 has periodic cohomology ( @xcite , p. 157 ) .",
    "[ exl : special_linear ]    finite groups with periodic cohomology admit the following equivalent characterizations ( @xcite , theorem vi.9.5 , p. 157 ) .",
    "the following conditions are equivalent for a finite group @xmath110 .",
    "@xmath110 has periodic cohomology .",
    "every abelian subgroup of @xmath110 is cyclic .",
    "the sylow subgroups of @xmath110 are cyclic or generalized quaternion groups .",
    "[ thm : brown_characterization_periodic_cohomology ]    using this characterization the following classification by suzuki @xcite becomes available .",
    "let @xmath110 be a finite group such that    sylow subgroups of odd order are cyclic .",
    "the 2-sylow subgroup is a generalized quaternion group .",
    "then @xmath110 contains a normal subgroup @xmath118 such that @xmath119\\leq 2 $ ] and @xmath120 for some prime @xmath115 where @xmath121 is a solvable group whose sylow subgroups are all cyclic .",
    "[ thm : suzuki_all_abelian_subgroups_cyclic ]    the case where all sylow subgroups are cyclic has been treated by burnside ( @xcite , chapter ix.128 , p. 163 ) .",
    "a proof can also be found in ( @xcite , lemma 5.4.3 , p. 163 ) .    if all sylow subgroups of a finite group @xmath110 are cyclic , then @xmath110 is solvable .",
    "[ thm : burnside_all_sylows_cyclic ]    from the preceding two results we conclude the following proposition .",
    "a finite and nontrivial perfect group @xmath110 with periodic cohomology is isomorphic to @xmath122 for some prime @xmath123 .",
    "[ prp : perfect_periodic_cohomology ]    according to theorem [ thm : brown_characterization_periodic_cohomology ] , all sylow subgroups of @xmath110 are either cyclic or generalized quaternion groups .",
    "the case where all sylow subgoups are cyclic can not occur by theorem [ thm : burnside_all_sylows_cyclic ] . otherwise , we are in the situation of theorem [ thm : suzuki_all_abelian_subgroups_cyclic ] , since all @xmath124-sylow subgroups are conjugate by sylow s theorem .",

    "then we have @xmath133 and @xmath2 has periodic cohomology .",
    "[ prp : connection - group - topological - homology ]    writing @xmath134 we have an exact sequence of @xmath2-modules @xmath135 where each @xmath136 is free and the @xmath110-action on @xmath137 is trivial .",
    "therefore , we can splice together an infinite number of copies of this sequence to obtain a periodic and complete resolution of @xmath137 over @xmath138 $ ] .",
    "hence , @xmath2 has periodic cohomology .",
    "because of @xmath139 the claim on @xmath140 follows , too .",
    "now we describe the typical situation in which we apply this proposition .",

    ". then the quotient space @xmath150 inherits a natural @xmath26-invariant triangulation .",

    "this enables us to determine the finite subgroups of @xmath49 based on the knowledge of the finite subgroups of @xmath181 . these are cyclic groups @xmath182 of order @xmath63 , dihedral groups @xmath183 of order @xmath184 and the symmetry groups of a tetrahedron , an octahedron and an icosahedron .",

    "let @xmath11 be a finite subgroup such that the quotient space @xmath4 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 .",
    "the purpose of this section is to show that @xmath2 has a form as described in our main theorem . in order to organize the argument",
    ", we introduce the following notions .      to a linear action @xmath274 of a finite subgroup @xmath275",
    "we associate a system of subgroups @xmath276 of @xmath2 and a system of linear subspaces @xmath277 of @xmath5 as follows .",
    "let @xmath276 be the system of subgroups of @xmath2 and let @xmath277 be the system of linear subspaces of @xmath5 such that    @xmath278 for @xmath279 if and only if there exists a linear subspace @xmath108 of @xmath5 such that @xmath280 .",
    "@xmath281 for a linear subspace @xmath108 of @xmath5 if and only if there exists a subgroup @xmath279 such that @xmath282 .",
    "inclusion induces partial orders on @xmath277 and @xmath276 .",
    "the group @xmath2 acts by translation on @xmath277 and by conjugation on @xmath276 .",
    "the correspondence @xmath283 is order - reversing , one - to - one and @xmath2-equivariant .",
    "note that @xmath284 is the maximal subgroup of @xmath2 that fixes @xmath108 pointwise .",
    "the equivalence classes under the action of @xmath2 are in one - to - one correspondence to the strata of @xmath4 and the type of a stratum is given by the corresponding subgroup in @xmath276 .",
    "we say that a subgroup @xmath278 is _ minimal _ if it is a nontrivial minimal subgroup in @xmath276 with respect to inclusion .",
    "corresponding subspaces are called _ maximal _ subspaces in @xmath277 . minimal subgroups and maximal subspaces correspond to strata of @xmath4 that are not contained in the closure of any higher dimensional irregular stratum .",
    "moreover , we introduce the following useful notations .",
    "define @xmath285 , @xmath286 and @xmath287 .    since @xmath288 is closed under the action of @xmath2 , the subgroup @xmath289 is normal in @xmath2 .",
    "we need the following two lemmas .    for a linear action @xmath274 of a finite subgroup @xmath29 and a point @xmath290 we have @xmath291 .",

    "then the action @xmath295 is free if and only if @xmath23 is minimal .",

    "each topological manifold is in particular a homology manifold .",
    "consequently , the quotient space @xmath4 for a finite subgroup @xmath11 must be a homology manifold in order to be homeomorphic to @xmath5 .",
    "so , for the rest of this section , we assume that @xmath11 is a finite subgroup such that @xmath4 is a homology manifold . according to lemma [ lem : characterization_of_homology_manifolds ] ,",
    "this means that @xmath21 has the homology groups of an @xmath103-sphere and is again a homology manifold .",
    "hence , by lemma [ lem : orientation_preservation ] we can assume that @xmath30 .",
    "moreover , the first condition is global , whereas the second condition is local .",
    "each point in @xmath296 has a neighborhood which is a homology manifold .",
    "a suitable neighborhood is homeomorphic to @xmath297 via the exponential map .",
    "hence , we conclude that @xmath298 is a homology manifold for all @xmath290 .",
    "proceeding iteratively we find that for each @xmath278 the quotient space of the action @xmath299 is a homology manifold .",
    "moreover , if @xmath23 is a minimal subgroup of @xmath2 , then @xmath300 is a homology sphere , since in this case the action @xmath301 is free by lemma [ lem : free_minimal ] .",
    "the next proposition shows that only very special minimal subgroups can occur .",

    "hence , we have shown that all poincar groups act in orthogonal spaces .",

    "again , we claim that @xmath431 for every nontrivial @xmath432 .",
    "if this were not true , then @xmath392 would be a rotation in the two - dimensional plane @xmath434 .",
    "but this is impossible , since @xmath392 is a rotation in the two - dimensional plane @xmath437 .",
    "moreover , in both cases @xmath436 is not orthogonal to @xmath438 , since the intersection @xmath439 is nontrivial by dimension reasons .",
    "therefore , if @xmath415 were wrong , @xmath277 would contain two different maximal subspaces with codimension four whose orthogonal complements are not orthogonal .",
    "this contradicts lemma [ lem : poincares_are_orthogonal ] and hence the claim follows .",
    "this completes the proof about the claimed orthogonal splitting .",
    "let @xmath274 be a linear action of a finite subgroup @xmath30 such that the quotient space is a homology manifold .",
    "in the preceding sections we have seen that the normal subgroup @xmath289 of @xmath2 is generated by the pseudoreflection subgroup of @xmath2 and certain poincar groups and that it splits as a direct product of these . in this section we show that @xmath440 holds .",

    "[ lem : free - action ]    assume there are @xmath444 , @xmath445 and @xmath81 such that @xmath446 .",
    "then @xmath447 and so @xmath448 .",
    "[ lem : homology_manifold_simplyconnected ] let @xmath449 with a pseudoreflection group @xmath15 and poincar groups @xmath450 , @xmath17 , such that the factors act in orthogonal spaces .",
    "then the quotient space @xmath4 is a homology manifold and @xmath21 is simply connected unless @xmath107 and @xmath20 or @xmath451 .",
    "the quotient space @xmath4 is a homology manifold by mikhalova s theorem [ thm : mikhailova ] and the fact that @xmath52 is a homology sphere in combination with lemma [ lem : characterization_of_homology_manifolds ] .",
    "if @xmath452 and @xmath453 , then @xmath21 is simply connected by mikhalova s theorem . if @xmath454 and if @xmath18 in the case @xmath20 , then @xmath21 can be written as the join of two topological spaces ( @xcite , proposition i.5.15 , p. 64 ) and as such it is simply connected .",
    "now we are in the position to complete the last step of our argument .",
    "recall the remark from the end of section [ sec : the_double_suspension_theorem ] : there are topological spaces @xmath65 such that @xmath79 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 whereas @xmath65 is not even a topological manifold .",
    "hence , the induction argument in the following lemma would not work , if the assumption `` homology '' were replaced by `` topological '' .",
    "in particular , we can not assume that the quotient space @xmath21 is simply connected , an assumption that would simplify the proof considerably .",
    "[ lem : gamma_gamma_mini]let @xmath274 be a linear action of a finite subgroup @xmath30 such that the quotient space is a homology manifold .",
    "then we have @xmath440 .",
    "the proof is by induction on @xmath63 .",
    "for @xmath455 and @xmath106 all finite subgroups of @xmath456 are generated by pseudoreflections , so nothing has to be shown .",
    "now let @xmath457 be fixed and assume that the claim holds for @xmath458 .",
    "we are going to show that it also holds for @xmath63 . for @xmath290",
    "the quotient space @xmath459 is a homology manifold and so we have @xmath460 by induction .",
    "lemma [ lem : stabilizer_minimizer_inclusion ] implies @xmath461 and thus @xmath462 for all @xmath290 .",
    "therefore , the action @xmath463 is free by lemma [ lem : free - action ] . since @xmath4 is a homology manifold by assumption and @xmath464 is a homology manifold by lemma [ lem : homology_manifold_simplyconnected ] , it follows from section [ subsec : free_actions_on_homology_spheres ] that @xmath465 has periodic cohomology and that @xmath466 next , we claim that @xmath465 is a perfect group . for @xmath107 and @xmath467",
    "we have @xmath468 , since the action must be free , and so we are done in this case .",
    "otherwise , the quotient space @xmath469 is simply connected by lemma [ lem : homology_manifold_simplyconnected ] and so we have @xmath470 , i.e. @xmath465 is a perfect group .",
    "hence , @xmath465 is a perfect group with periodic cohomology .",
    "therefore , proposition [ prp : perfect_periodic_cohomology ] implies that @xmath465 is either trivial or isomorphic to @xmath122 for some prime @xmath123 .",
    "we want to exclude the second case . in the case @xmath18 this follows from proposition [ prp : third - homology - of - special - linear ] and equation ( [ eqn : homology_groups_of_quotient ] ) .",
    "we have already treated the case @xmath107 and @xmath467 .",
    "hence , for @xmath107 we can assume that @xmath471 .",
    "but then lemma [ lem : normal_subgroup_generated_by_ps_in_dim4 ] implies @xmath472 and @xmath473 , a contradiction .",
    "consequently , we conclude that @xmath440 holds for @xmath63 and so the claim follows by induction .    summarizing , we have shown :    [ prp : summary_ifdirection]let @xmath274 be a linear action of a finite subgroup @xmath11 .",
    "if the quotient space @xmath4 is a homology manifold , then @xmath2 has the form @xmath14 for a pseudoreflection group @xmath15 and poincar groups @xmath16 , @xmath17 , such that the factors act in pairwise orthogonal spaces .",
    "[ thm : theorem_a ] for a finite subgroup @xmath11 the quotient space @xmath4 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 if and only if @xmath2 has the form @xmath14 for a pseudoreflection group @xmath15 and poincar groups @xmath16 , @xmath17 , such that the factors act in pairwise orthogonal spaces and such that @xmath18 if @xmath20 .    in proposition",
    "[ prp : summary_ifdirection ] we have seen that @xmath2 must have a form as described in the theorem if the quotient space @xmath4 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 .",
    "moreover , the additional condition that @xmath18 if @xmath20 must also hold . for , @xmath75 is not even a topological manifold .",
    "conversely , assume that @xmath2 has a form as described in the theorem . in the case",
    "@xmath474 we can successively apply mikhalova s theorem and then @xmath244-times the double suspension theorem to show that @xmath4 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 .",
    "the latter is possible , since after dividing out the pseudoreflection group there is always a trivial fifth factor available not involving any action . in the same way",
    ", the case @xmath475 can be reduced to the case @xmath476 and @xmath477 .",
    "because of @xmath478 , in this case the claim follows if we can show that @xmath479 is a topological sphere .",
    "to see this we realize @xmath480 and @xmath481 as simplicial complexes @xmath482 and @xmath483 with triangulations coming from the unique piecewise linear structure of @xmath53 .",
    "then @xmath484 is in a natural way again a simplical complex and it realizes the space @xmath65 . since the action @xmath24 is free , all the links of @xmath482 and @xmath483 are topological @xmath124-spheres . hence , for a vertex @xmath485 we have @xmath486 by the double suspension theorem .",
    "therefore , theorem [ thm : simplicialcomplex_hommfd ] implies that @xmath65 is a topological manifold .",
    "since @xmath75 is a homology manifold , so is @xmath487 and thus @xmath65 has the homology groups of @xmath488 by lemma [ lem : characterization_of_homology_manifolds ] .",
    "moreover , @xmath65 is simply connected as the join of two spaces .",
    "consequently , @xmath65 is a simply connected homology sphere and as such even a topological sphere by the generalized poincar conjecture in the form of theorem [ thm : gen_poin_conj ] .",
    "this completes the proof by the remark above .    for a smooth orbifold @xmath0",
    "the action of local groups on charts is always linearizable by the differentiable slice theorem ( @xcite , theorem 1.5 , p. 3 ) .",
    "therefore , we obtain the following immediate corollary .    the underlying topological space of a smooth orbifold @xmath0 is a topological manifold , if and only if the linearizations of all local groups have a form as described in theorem [ thm : theorem_a ] .",
    "to prove theorem b we need the following properties of pseudoreflection groups .",
    "[ prp : isotropy_property_of_ps ] let @xmath489 be a pseudoreflection group .",
    "then for each @xmath290 the isotropy group @xmath490 is again a pseudoreflection group .    by mikhalova",
    "s theorem @xmath491 is homeomorphic to @xmath5 and so it follows from section [ sec : theorem ] and , in particular , lemma [ lem : gamma_gamma_mini ] that @xmath492 . since minimal subgroups of the action",
    "@xmath493 are also minimal subgroups of the action @xmath494 and since the latter one has no poincar subgroups as minimal subgroups , neither has the first one .",
    "this shows that @xmath492 is generated by pseudoreflections due to proposition [ prp : characterization_minimal_subgroup_top ] .",
    "[ prp : quotient_of_ps ] let @xmath489 be a pseudoreflection group .",
    "then the quotient space @xmath495 is homeomorphic to @xmath22 .",
    "let @xmath489 be a pseudoreflection group .",
    "choose a @xmath15-invariant triangulation of @xmath22 by a simplicial complex @xmath102 such that the action of @xmath15 on @xmath103-simplices is free .",
    "this induces a triangulation of the quotient space @xmath495 by a simplicial complex @xmath496 .",
    "since @xmath495 is simply connected and has the homology groups of a @xmath103-sphere by lemma [ lem : homology_manifold_simplyconnected ] and lemma [ lem : characterization_of_homology_manifolds ] , due to the generalized poincar conjecture it suffices to show that @xmath495 is a topological manifold in order to prove the claim .",
    "indeed , the links of all vertices of @xmath497 are quotients of spheres by isotropy groups of @xmath15 , i.e. by pseudoreflection groups due to proposition [ prp : isotropy_property_of_ps ] .",
    "hence , they are simply connected by proposition [ lem : homology_manifold_simplyconnected ] and thus theorem [ thm : simplicialcomplex_hommfd ] implies that @xmath495 is a topological manifold .",
    "[ thm : theorem_b ] for a finite subgroup @xmath11 the quotient space @xmath21 is homeomorphic to @xmath22 if and only if @xmath2 has the form @xmath14 for a pseudoreflection group @xmath15 and poincar groups @xmath16 , @xmath17 , such that the factors act in pairwise orthogonal spaces and such that @xmath498 if @xmath20 .    by proposition",
    "[ prp : summary_ifdirection ] @xmath2 must have a form as described in the theorem if the quotient space @xmath21 is homeomorphic to @xmath22 .",
    "moreover , the additional condition that @xmath498 if @xmath20 must also hold . for , @xmath52 is not simply connected and @xmath499 is not even a topological manifold .",

    "hence , the claim follows from the double suspension theorem in the case @xmath501 and as in the proof of theorem a , otherwise .",
    "i am grateful to alexander lytchak for his encouragement to start this work and his guidance to this fruitful approach .",
    "i thank anton petrunin for revealing the geometric meaning of lemma [ lem : angle_reduction ] .",

    "319 , springer - verlag , berlin , 1999 .",
    "mr1744486 ( 2000k:53038 )            albrecht dold , _ lectures on algebraic topology _ ,",
    ", grundlehren der mathematischen wissenschaften [ fundamental principles of mathematical sciences ] , vol . 200 , springer - verlag , berlin , 1980 . mr606196 ( 82c:55001 )    michael w. davis , _ lectures on orbifolds and reflection groups _ , transformation groups and moduli spaces of curves , adv .",
    "lect . math .",
    "( alm ) , vol .",
    "press , somerville , ma , 2011 , pp .",
    "mr2883685        robert d. edwards , _ the topology of manifolds and cell - like maps _ , proceedings of the international congress of mathematicians ( helsinki , 1978 ) , acad .",
    "fennica , helsinki , 1980 , pp .",
    "111 - 127 .",
    "mr562601 ( 81g:57010 )      greg leibon and david letscher , _ delaunay triangulations and voronoi diagrams for riemannian manifolds _ , ( hong kong , 2000 ) , acm , new york , 2000 , pp . 341 - 349 ( electronic ) , doi 10.1145/336154.336221 .",
    "mr1802283 ( 2001i:53011 )"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we answer the question posed by davis : `` when is the underlying space of an orbifold a topological manifold '' . </S>",
    "<S> it amounts to the classification of finite groups acting linearly on a euclidean vector space such that the quotient space is homeomorphic to the original vector space . </S>",
    "<S> we also treat the corresponding problem for actions on unit spheres . </S>"
  ]
}
